title: How to Hang Patterned Wallpaper

parts.name: Measuring and Cutting the First Strip

steps.headline: Measure the height of the wall using a measuring tape and add 4 in (10 cm).
steps.description: Stretch out a measuring tape from ceiling to floor and read the number to get the ceiling height. Add 4 in (10 cm) to the measurement to allow for adjustments to get the patterns to line up correctly.Tip: If you’re new to hanging patterned wallpaper, it’s best to start with a relatively simple pattern. This will make it much easier to align the strips and allow more room for error. You’ll be able to cut off the excess paper at the top and bottom once the wallpaper is pasted to the wall.

steps.headline: Unroll a roll of wallpaper facedown on a pasting table.
steps.description: Place the roll of wallpaper at 1 end of the pasting table. Carefully unroll it to the other end so it is flat on the table with the backside exposed. A pasting table is a special kind of flat folding table, usually made out of pinewood, that is ideal for applying paste to wallpaper. If you don’t have a pasting table, you can use another kind of flat surface that has no bumps or other irregularities.

steps.headline: Transfer the ceiling measurement to the back of the wallpaper and mark it.
steps.description: Measure from the end of the wallpaper using your measuring team and make a small mark with a pencil. Line up a ruler across the wallpaper where you made the mark and draw a straight line. It’s best if you use a long ruler that can stretch across the entire width of the wallpaper so you can make a perfectly straight line. You could also use a carpenter’s square or level if you only have a standard-length ruler.

steps.headline: Cut off the excess wallpaper using a box cutter.
steps.description: Place your ruler or another straight edge along the line you marked. Cut along it carefully with a box cutter to separate the first strip of wallpaper from the roll. You could also use a sharp pair of scissors to cut along the line if you have a steady hand. Since there will be excess wallpaper at the top and bottom, it’s OK if the cut is not perfect, as you will cut off the excess after hanging the wallpaper.

parts.name: Gluing the First Piece of Wallpaper

steps.headline: Mix some wallpaper adhesive in a container using a mixing stick.
steps.description: Mix the wallpaper adhesive in a clean plastic container according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Wait for the amount of time specified in the instructions for the glue to be ready to use. Most wallpaper adhesive is ready to use within 15-20 minutes. Mixing sticks are flat wooden sticks used for mixing paint and other substances used in home improvement projects. You can get one wherever you can buy wallpaper and wallpaper adhesive.

steps.headline: Apply the adhesive to the back of the wallpaper using a paste brush.
steps.description: Dip the paste brush in the wallpaper glue and start spreading it in the middle of the back of the wallpaper. Spread it from the center outwards, dipping the brush in more paste as needed. A paste brush is a large brush specifically made for applying wallpaper adhesive and other types of glues to various surfaces. They are slightly softer than a paintbrush, although you could use a soft paintbrush as an alternative.

steps.headline: Fold the bottom 1/3 of the wallpaper back over itself loosely.
steps.description: Carefully pick up the bottom end of the wallpaper, where you cut it, and fold it up over itself so the top 1/3 is still exposed. This will make it easier to work with as you hang it.Warning: Be very careful not to crease the wallpaper where you fold it. Leave it in a loose rounded shape where it doubles back on itself. Don’t worry about the glued sides sticking together. Wallpaper adhesive is very slow to dry.

steps.headline: Glue the strip at the top of the wall, overlapping the ceiling by 2 in (5.1 cm).
steps.description: Start in a corner at the ceiling and hold the top 1/3 of the wallpaper against the wall loosely so about 2 in (5.1 cm) is overlapping the ceiling. Make sure the strip is straight and aligned evenly with the corner of the wall, ceiling, and floor, then press the top section against the wall so it sticks. You’ll cut off the overlapping paper at the top after you’ve glued the whole strip, so just leave it loose for now.

steps.headline: Smooth out the wallpaper using a wallpaper brush.
steps.description: Push a wallpaper brush from the center outwards towards the sides and top of the section you just pasted. This will remove air bubbles and ensure the wallpaper is glued smoothly to the wall. A wallpaper brush is a wide brush made specifically for hanging wallpaper. Don’t confuse it with the paste brush that you used to apply the glue.

steps.headline: Unfold the wallpaper and paste the rest to the wall, smoothing it out as you go.
steps.description: Carefully unfold the bottom 1/3 of the paper that you doubled back over itself. Paste the rest of the strip to the wall from the top down, then smooth it out from the center outwards using the wallpaper brush. Make sure to look closely at the strip as you work for any trapped pockets of air and smooth them out towards the edges with the wallpaper brush.

steps.headline: Use a smoothing tool and a box cutter to cut off excess paper at the ends.
steps.description: Push the wallpaper tightly into the creases at the top and bottom with a wallpaper smoothing tool. Use the smoothing tool as a cutting guide, slicing along it with the box cutter to remove the excess wallpaper at the top and bottom of the wall along the ceiling and baseboards. A wallpaper smoothing tool is a wide, flat plastic tool made for pushing wallpaper into creases.

parts.name: Lining up and Pasting the Next Strips

steps.headline: Measure and cut the second strip.
steps.description: Use your measuring tape to measure the ceiling height plus 4 in (10 cm) from the cut end down and make a mark at the edge of the paper with your pencil. Draw a straight line across the width of the paper from the mark to the opposite side, then cut along it with a box cutter or scissors. It’s important to always remember to measure the ceiling height plus 4 in (10 cm) so you have excess paper that allows you to line the patterns up perfectly.

steps.headline: Position the second strip next to the first to ensure the pattern lines up.
steps.description: Dry fit the wallpaper next to the first strip you hung and line up the patterns vertically and horizontally, making sure the new strip is straight on the wall and even with the ceiling and floor. Take the strip back to the pasting table and lay it face-down once you are happy that it will fit properly next to the first strip. It’s always a good idea to check the fit while the paper is dry before gluing it to the wall to double-check. That way, if you made any errors while measuring you aren’t stuck with a piece of wallpaper that has glue on the back that won’t fit. Note that you are not overlapping the strips of wallpaper, but rather butting the edges up against one another as tightly as you can without overlapping them at all.

steps.headline: Apply glue to the back of the second strip.
steps.description: Spread the wallpaper glue from the center outwards using your paste brush as you did with the first piece of wallpaper. Make sure you cover it all right to the edges.

steps.headline: Fold the bottom 1/3 of the paper loosely back over itself.
steps.description: Use the same technique you used for the first piece. Be careful not to crease the paper where you fold it over itself or it won’t look good on the wall.

steps.headline: Paste the second strip next to the first, unfolding and smoothing it as you go.
steps.description: Hold the second strip of wallpaper by the top edge and place it against the wall loosely, aligning the patterns carefully. Stick it to the wall and smooth it out with the wallpaper brush. Unfold the bottom 1/3 of the strip, paste it carefully so the patterns line up, and smooth it out from the top to bottom. Remember to brush out air bubbles from the center towards the edges.

steps.headline: Smooth the seams between the strips using a wallpaper seam roller.
steps.description: Roll from top to bottom along the seam where the 2 pieces of wallpaper meet. Roll up and down over any areas where the seam looks uneven or has bubbles until it is totally smooth. A wallpaper seam roller is a small plastic roller made specifically for smoothing out the seams between pieces of wallpaper.

steps.headline: Cut off excess paper at the bottom using your box cutter and smoothing tool.
steps.description: Push the top and bottom edges of the wallpaper into the creases where it meets the ceiling and baseboards. Use the box cutter to cut along it and remove the excess overlapping paper at the top and bottom.

steps.headline: Repeat the process for the following strips of wallpaper.
steps.description: Follow all the same steps to align, paste, and smooth out each proceeding strip of wallpaper. Keep working your way around the room in the same direction until you have covered all the walls that you want to.Tip: If you have to paste any wallpaper around obstacles like window frames, use the same technique you used to trim off excess paper at the top on bottom of pieces. Push the wallpaper into the creases around the obstacle with the smoothing tool, then use it as a guide to cut off the excess with a box cutter. Once you get to a corner, use the smoothing tool and box cutter to trim off excess paper at the side, leaving about a 0.5 in (1.3 cm) overlap on the next wall. Always start in the corner of a new wall with a fresh strip of wallpaper and overlap it with the excess 0.5 in (1.3 cm) of the last piece on the new wall so the patterns line up. The corners are the only spots you ever overlap wallpaper. You could also use the off-cut excess paper from the last piece to start the new wall if it’s easier to line up the patterns.
